citations.narrative:
The acquisition record dated 30 May 2024 for a coyote "Penny" is incomplete and does not have the name and address
of the individual donating the animal. The record states that the individual wants to remain anonymous. Failure to record
required information in acquisition records of regulated animals inhibits APHIS Officials' duties to trace animal movement
and assess compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully
and correctly disclose information required in CFR sections 2.75 (b)(1)(i-vii) in the acquisition and disposition of animals
other than dogs and cats.
Correct by 10 January 2025.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The facility representative could not locate certain required records such as the written Program of Veterinary Care or
disposition records of animals such as 2 tigers, 2 racoons and a llama. The inability to locate required records during an
inspection impedes APHIS Officials' duties to assess facility compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. Each exhibitor shall
have a method for facility representatives to access required records for inspectors to evaluate during an inspection.
Correct by 10 January 2025.

The written contingency plan presented for inspection has not had an annual review since 2021. Failure to conduct annual
reviews of the contingency plan and maintain documentation thereof may result in poor preparation and poor animal
handling during emergencies and disasters. Contingency plans must be in place and reviewed annually to ensure it
adequately addresses the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this section and is still relevant to the facility and animals. The
plan must provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of animals in the event of an
emergency or disaster.
Correct by 10 January 2025.

The facility acquired 10 adult wolf-dog hybrids on 04 October 2024. At time of inspection, there is no written exercise plan
for dogs available for review. Failure to have a written exercise plan for dogs may result in poor health and psychological
welfare of the animals. Each exhibitor conducting regulated activity with dogs or hybrids such as wolf-dog hybrids, must
follow an appropriate written exercise plan that is approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 10 January 2025.

The facility acquired 10 adult wolf-dog hybrids on 04 October 2024. At time of inspection, there is no written Program of
Veterinary Care for dogs available for review. Failure to have a written program of veterinary care for dogs may result in
poor health and welfare management of the animals. Each exhibitor conducting regulated activity with dogs or hybrids
such as wolf-dog hybrids, must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing
and signed by the attending veterinarian. The program of veterinary care must address all elements listed in CFR sections
3.13(a)(1-4).
Correct by 10 January 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)(i) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The acquisition record dated 30 May 2024 for a coyote "Penny" is incomplete and does not have the name and address 
of the individual donating the animal. The record states that the individual wants to remain anonymous. Failure to record 
required information in acquisition records of regulated animals inhibits APHIS Officials' duties to trace animal movement 
and assess compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully 
and correctly disclose information required in CFR sections 2.75 (b)(1)(i-vii) in the acquisition and disposition of animals 
other than dogs and cats. 
 
Correct by 10 January 2025. 
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The facility representative could not locate certain required records such as the written Program of Veterinary Care or 
disposition records of animals such as 2 tigers, 2 racoons and a llama. The inability to locate required records during an 
inspection impedes APHIS Officials' duties to assess facility compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. Each exhibitor shall 
have a method for facility representatives to access required records for inspectors to evaluate during an inspection.  
 
Correct by 10 January 2025. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The written contingency plan presented for inspection has not had an annual review since 2021. Failure to conduct annual 
reviews of the contingency plan and maintain documentation thereof may result in poor preparation and poor animal 
handling during emergencies and disasters. Contingency plans must be in place and reviewed annually to ensure it 
adequately addresses the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this section and is still relevant to the facility and animals. The 
plan must provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of animals in the event of an 
emergency or disaster.

Correct by 10 January 2025. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The facility acquired 10 adult wolf-dog hybrids on 04 October 2024. At time of inspection, there is no written exercise plan 
for dogs available for review. Failure to have a written exercise plan for dogs may result in poor health and psychological 
welfare of the animals. Each exhibitor conducting regulated activity with dogs or hybrids such as wolf-dog hybrids, must 
follow an appropriate written exercise plan that is approved by the attending veterinarian.  
 
Correct by 10 January 2025. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility acquired 10 adult wolf-dog hybrids on 04 October 2024. At time of inspection, there is no written Program of 
Veterinary Care for dogs available for review. Failure to have a written program of veterinary care for dogs may result in 
poor health and welfare management of the animals. Each exhibitor conducting regulated activity with dogs or hybrids 
such as wolf-dog hybrids, must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing 
and signed by the attending veterinarian. The program of veterinary care must address all elements listed in CFR sections 
3.13(a)(1-4).  
 
Correct by 10 January 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
